title: Does your guy have a wandering eye? British men admit to secretly snapping photos of bikini-clad women at the beach on holiday with their partner

British men love sightseeing so much on their holiday in the sun that they’re not afraid to go snap happy with their cameras – but it’s a different type of eye candy that is catching their attention.
Fourteen per cent of male holidaymakers admitted in a recent survey to sneakily taking pictures of women at the beach or pool.
The troubling revelation will no doubt raise concerns about privacy and decency, and questions about whether laws are being broken by the camera-toting tourists.
More than 2,100 male holidaymakers were surveyed, and 14% said they had photographed random women
According to the survey by sunshine.co.uk, 61 per cent of those polled admitted to ogling women they don’t know.
Half of those who snapped a photo were in a relationship at the time and most were on holiday with their partner, yet only one in eight admitted to getting caught.
The poll of 2,155 British men, who all had been abroad in the past 12 months, found 88 per cent of those who had ogled other women while holidaying with their other half were caught in the act.

The animal kingdom as you've never seen it before:... 11 shares Most men said they had taken pictures ‘because I appreciated their beauty and wanted to remember it’ (51 per cent) while a further 32 per cent wanted to show their mates back home.
Even though they were OK with photographing a stranger, most men said they would have felt less than happy to know their own wife or girlfriend was being surreptitiously photographed by a man.
Three-quarters said they would be ‘furious’, with only 11 per cent claiming they would feel ‘proud’.
Half of those who snapped a photo were in a relationship and most were on holiday with their partner
Chris Clarkson, managing director of sunshine.co.uk, said: ‘There's no denying that these findings are really alarming.
‘Women should be able to relax on holiday and not have to have their wits about them 100 per cent of the time. Men have no right to photograph scantily-clad women that they do not know in secret. It's very wrong.
‘When we asked how men would feel if it was their wife or girlfriend in front of the camera, we found that most of them would quite rightly be furious.
‘It made us realise that a few of those men must be very hypocritical, given that some were also guilty of photographing women in secret.’
